dlgPart.npc_text: "Business or pleasure?" inquires an old man sitting on one of the graves.
"Not the brightest torch, are you <boy/girl>? If you have business with me, then you're here on business. If it's the pleasure of my company that you're seeking, then that would be pleasure."

"Business it is. Well then, let's get to it, shall we? It's five coins for a group grave. For those who were accustomed to the finer things in life and undoubtedly expect the same quality in their afterlife, they can have an individual spot for the low price of just ten coins – quite a deal, isn't it, my friend?"

dlgAnsw.text: "Got it. What was the other option?"

dlgPart.npc_text: "If it's the pleasure of my company that you're seeking, then that would be pleasure. It isn't free, mind you. I'm what some might call the town's historian, so if you're looking to educate your dumb self, look no further. Five dead emperors, please."
"The pleasure of my company, which isn't free, mind you. I'm what some might call the town's historian, so if you're looking to educate your dumb self, look no further. Five dead emperors, please."
"The pleasure of my company isn't free, mind you. I'm what some might call the town's historian, so if you're looking to educate your dumb self, look no further. Five dead emperors, please."

"Much obliged," says the undertaker, accepting the coins before expertly biting each one to test the gold content.
"So, Teron... A real pearl, isn't it? It has this rare quality that I have yet to find anywhere else. Of course, I haven't been anywhere else – born and raised in Teron, but still... from what I hear it's nothing but a certifiable truth."

"Like many towns, it started out as a camp. That's right, you heard it here first. The Imperial army swept through this land like a tidal wave and washed away any soul that dared to oppose them. After that, the legions stopped right here – on this very spot that you now stand on – and made a proper camp with ramparts, stakes, the works.
"It was a clever strategy seeing as how such camps were a series of stepping stones going in every direction, ensuring that the army was never more than a day away from the nearest base and supplies. See, back in the day, they really knew how to run things and make some sense out of them. You see, that's what we're missing today."

"So, out of all the camps in the area, this one was chosen to become a town – a foundation, a pillar of strength, a hold over the conquered territory. And guess what, we're still here. We're still holding the line. So many towns had crumbled into dust, yet Teron's still standing. Now that's something to be proud of, aint it?"
"Now we stand until relieved. The Empire will rise again and when it does, Teron will be restored to its former glory and we'll shine again. You'll see."

"We are the scions of the Empire! It's in our blood. All we have to do is show the gods that we're worthy, that we still have the fucking balls!
"Of course, I don't see it happening any time soon, at least not while the Lords are squabbling..."

"There is only one true House and that's Daratan. Before the war, no House was mightier or more decorated. The Lords of Daratan have always stood one step behind the Emperor, which was the highest honor.
"Now it's up to Antidas to take a step forward and assume the mantle."

dlgAnsw.text: "What about House Aurelian or House Crassus?"

dlgPart.npc_text:
"House Aurelian? When have *they* ever done anything? Hah, it was a third-rate House that never amounted to anything, other than seizing Maadoran.
"As for House Crassus, it was a House of Magi – good for fucking things up, but little else, you know? Seeing as how that magic is gone from the world, they're as useless as tits on a bull."

dlgAnsw.text: "And how do you know all that?"

dlgPart.npc_text: "I used to serve a loremaster, right up until he died. He was a man of learning - a real scholar. He taught me letters, so that I could serve him better, and gave me scrolls to read. Now, I'm an educated man, able to make a comfortable living."
